method.name: QAR_CIP_NSGAII

reference.ref: D. Martín, A. Rosete, J. Alcalá-Fdez and F. Herrera. QAR-CIP-NSGA-II: A new multi-objective evolutionary algorithm to mine quantitative association rules. Information Sciences, 258:1-28 (2014).

generalDescription.type: Association Rules Mining by means of Genetic Algorithms
generalDescription.objective: The multi-objective evolutionary algorithm mines a reduced set of positive and negative quatitative association rules that are interesting, easy to understand and with a good trade-off between the number of rules, support and coverage of the dataset.
generalDescription.howWork: The genetic learning is performed iteratively until a maximum number of evaluations is reached. First, the algorithm generates an initial population and initializes the external population (EP) with nondominated rules from the initial population. Then an offspring population is generated from the current population by selection, crossover and mutation. The next population is constructed from the current and offspring populations, the EP is updated with the current population and, if necessary, the restarting process is applied. At the end, the EP is returned. The NSGA-II algorithm has two features, which make it a high-performance MOEA. One is the fitness evaluation of each solution based on the Pareto ranking and a crowding measure, and the other is an elitist generation update procedure.

parameterSpec.param: Number of Objetives: the number of objectives to optimize
Number of Evaluations: the maximum number of evaluations to accomplish.
Population Size: the population size to handle after each generation.
Probability of Mutation: the probability of mutation.
The factor of amplitude for each attribute of the dataset: the amplitude factor related to each attribute of the database.
Difference threshold: the difference between the current population and previous population for which the population is restarted.

method.example:
Problem type: Association Rules Method: QAR-CIP-NSGA-II Dataset: basketball Parameters: default values (seed = 1286082570)
After the execution of RunKeel.jar we can see XML representations of the mined association rules along with the values concerning the measures of interest, respectively, in:
"results/Asso-QAR-CIP-NSGA-II.basketball/result0s0.tra"
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <rules> <rule id="0"> <antecedents> <attribute name="heightInteger" value="[160.0, 160.0]"/> </antecedents> <consequents> <attribute name="points_per_minuteReal" value="[0.2894, 0.2894]"/> </consequents> </rule> ... ... ... ... </rules>
"results/Asso-QAR-CIP-NSGA-II.basketball/result0s0.tst"
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <values> <rule id="0" rule_support="0.02" antecedent_support="0.02" consequent_support="0.02" confidence="1" lift="96" conviction="Infinity" certainFactor="1" netConf="1" yulesQ="1" nAttributes="2"/> ... ... ... ... </values>
Number of Association Rules generated: 190 Average Support: 0.03 Average Confidence: 0.99 Average Lift: 80.09 Average Conviction: Infinity Average Certain Factor: 0.98 Average Netconf: 0.95 Average yulesQ: 1.0 Average Number of Antecedents: 2.1 Number of Covered Records (%): 95.84
"results/Asso-QAR-CIP-NSGA-II.basketball/result0s0e0.tst"
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <values> Support antecedent_support consequent_support Confidence Lift Conv CF NetConf YulesQ nAttributes 0.02 0.02 0.02 1 96 Infinity 1 1 1 2 ... ... ... ... </values>
We can also see some relevant information on-screen:
Initialization Computing Generation 1 Computing Generation 2 ... ... ... ... Computing Generation 208 done.
Number of Association Rules generated: 190 Average Support: 0.03 Average Confidence: 0.99 Average Lift: 80.09 Average Conviction: Infinity Average Certain Factor: 0.98 Average Netconf: 0.95 Average yulesQ: 1.0 Average Number of Antecedents: 2.1 Number of Covered Records (%): 95.84
Algorithm Finished
0.65 seconds
